summary: This is the November 2020 Executive Summary of the Department of Justice Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) report investigating the conduct of prosecutors in the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida regarding the 2006-2008 federal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein. It examines the negotiation and execution of the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) and the office's interactions with victims, concluding the prosecutors did not commit professional misconduct but exercised poor judgment.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Multi-millionaire financier investigated for illegal sexual activity with minors. The subject of the federal investigation resolved by the Non-Prosecution Agreement in 2007.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.role: Former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, later U.S. Secretary of Labor
persons.context: The U.S. Attorney who made the pivotal decision to resolve the federal investigation through the NPA. He approved the agreement and was a primary subject of the OPR investigation.

persons.name: Ben Sasse
persons.role: U.S. Senator, Chairman of the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Oversight
persons.context: Sent a letter to OPR in December 2018 requesting an investigation into possible misconduct by DOJ attorneys following the Miami Herald report.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Nominated Alexander Acosta to be Secretary of Labor in 2017.

persons.name: Ron DeSantis
persons.context: Announced in August 2019 that he directed the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to open an investigation into the conduct of state authorities relating to Epstein.

persons.name: Julie K. Brown
persons.context: Author of the Miami Herald's November 2018 investigative report 'Perversion of Justice' which detailed the Epstein case and the NPA.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, was the lead federal prosecutor responsible for the investigation and ultimate resolution via the Non-Prosecution Agreement with Epstein.
Epstein, through his team of prominent attorneys, negotiated the NPA with Acosta's office and later appealed to senior DOJ officials to invalidate it.
Senator Sasse requested the OPR investigation that scrutinized Acosta's conduct in the Epstein case.
President Trump nominated Acosta for the position of Secretary of Labor.

events.title: Initial Police Complaint
events.description: Parents of a 14-year-old girl complained to the Palm Beach Police Department that Epstein had paid her for a massage, initiating the local investigation.

events.title: State Grand Jury Indictment
events.description: A Palm Beach County grand jury indicted Epstein for felony solicitation of prostitution.

events.title: Draft Federal Indictment Prepared
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney submitted a draft 60-count federal indictment against Epstein to her supervisors.

events.title: Initial Offer to Epstein's Attorneys
events.description: The USAO offered to end its federal investigation if Epstein pled guilty to state charges, served a minimum of two years' incarceration, registered as a sexual offender, and agreed to a victim compensation mechanism.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: The NPA was signed, requiring Epstein to plead guilty in state court to two charges and serve 18 months in county jail followed by 12 months of home detention, in exchange for the USAO ending its federal investigation and immunizing Epstein and named co-conspirators.

events.title: Epstein's State Guilty Plea and Sentencing
events.description: Epstein pled guilty in state court to felony solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors for prostitution. He was sentenced to 18 months incarceration (served 13) and 12 months home detention.

events.title: CVRA Lawsuit Filed
events.description: A victim, 'Jane Doe,' filed an emergency petition in federal court alleging the government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by not consulting victims before signing the NPA.

events.title: Miami Herald Investigation Published
events.description: Julie K. Brown's investigative report 'Perversion of Justice' was published, revealing details of the NPA and sparking public outrage and renewed scrutiny.

events.title: Court Finds CVRA Violation
events.description: The federal district court granted partial summary judgment to the CVRA petitioners, ruling the government violated the CVRA by not advising victims about the NPA and by sending misleading letters.

events.title: Federal Indictment in New York
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York obtained a federal grand jury indictment charging Epstein with sex trafficking of minors.

events.title: Epstein Arrested in New York
events.description: Epstein was arrested on the New York federal charges and ordered detained pending trial.

events.title: Acosta Resigns
events.description: Alexander Acosta submitted his resignation as U.S. Secretary of Labor.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan. The medical examiner ruled it a suicide.

locations: Florida Science Foundation, West Palm Beach
keyFacts: The OPR investigation concluded that the federal prosecutors, including Alexander Acosta, did not commit professional misconduct in negotiating the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, but that Acosta exercised 'poor judgment.'
The NPA immunized Epstein, four named co-conspirators, and 'any potential co-conspirators' from federal prosecution in the Southern District of Florida in exchange for a state guilty plea.
Victims were not informed of or consulted about the NPA before it was signed on September 24, 2007, a fact later ruled a violation of the Crime Victims' Rights Act by a federal court.

After the NPA was signed, the USAO and FBI sent letters to victims stating the case was 'under investigation,' which the court found misled victims, though OPR attributed this to an FBI administrative employee using standard form language.

The report details Epstein's efforts after signing the NPA to invalidate it by appealing to senior DOJ officials, arguing the matter was a 'quintessentially state matter,' an appeal which was ultimately rejected in June 2008.
